Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Effect of Variations in Cloud Versus CO2 Radiative Forcing on Tropical SST Gradients, Atmospheric Circulation and Rainfall Patterns
Award.AbstractNarration:
Simulations of the response of tropical climate to greenhouse gas increases show a prominent role for clouds in determining how much the tropics warm, how the warming is distributed geographically, and how it affects other aspects of the climate. Many aspects of tropical climate, including the distribution of rainfall and surface winds, are closely related to the east-west sea surface temperature (SST) gradient along the equatorial Pacific, between the warm pool of the western Pacific and the cold tongue extending from the eastern boundary. Previous work by the PIs shows a strong relationship between the SST gradient in the equatorial Pacific and the contrast in brightness, or albedo, between tropical and extratropical clouds. The PIs have developed a theory to explain this connection, in which extratropical clouds with higher albedo imply less sunlight absorbed by the ocean at higher latitudes, which in turn requires greater heat transport from the tropics, which is satisfied by greater oceanic heat uptake in the cold tongue and subsequent oceanic transport, which requires colder temperatures in the cold tongue and thus a greater temperature contrast between the cold tongue and the warm pool.

Motivated by this theoretical framework, the PIs test the hypothesis that latitudinal variations in the response of cloud albedo to greenhouse warming play a key role in driving changes in tropical climate associated with the east-west SST contrast across the Pacific. The PIs perform greenhouse warming simulations with the Community Earth System Model (CESM) in n fully coupled, slab ocean, and prescribed SST configurations, in which cloud feedbacks and their effects on the equatorial Pacific SST contrast are assessed. Complimentary analysis of greenhouse warming simulations from the archive of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project version 5 (CMIP5) is also performed. As ocean heat transport plays an important role, a water parcel tracking scheme is applied to identify the location and time of last ventilation for water in the equatorial mixed layer, which can then be related to cloud radiative effects felt by the parcel during ventilation.

The research has broader societal impacts as it addresses fundamental issues in tropical climate which are essential for anticipating future climate changes in a populous region. The work has broader scientific impacts because the results will likely be helpful for understanding warm climates of the past, in particular the Pliocene, a period 3-5 million years ago when carbon dioxide levels were as high as today and the equatorial Pacific SST gradient is believed to have been weaker. The work has additional educational broader impacts through the participation of one of the PIs in National Center for Science Education "Scientists in the Classroom" pilot project, in which she will work with a middle school teachers and students. In addition, the project provides support and training to a graduate student and a postdoc, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to enhance our understanding of the fundamental physical mechanisms controlling tropical climate, with global implications for atmospheric circulation and the hydrological cycle, especially in the context of anthropogenic climate change. As such, the findings from this research are relevant to a broad range of disciplines interested in how atmospheric circulation patterns and the hydrological cycle have changed in the past and will change in the future, from physical climate sciences to ecology, botany, paleoceanography, and economics.  The project explored key aspects of the response of the tropical Pacific to radiative forcing and, specifically, compared the impact of changes in cloud radiative forcing against the resolved response to CO2 forcing, emphasizing the role of both tropical and extratropical cloud feedbacks in determining the response of the tropics to climate change. Our most novel scientific findings demonstrate

(1) That accurately predicting the response of the hydrological cycle to global warming requires predicting not only how global mean temperature responds to elevated CO2 forcing (climate sensitivity) but also correctly quantifying how meridional sea surface temperature patterns will change (structural climate sensitivity). The latter effect controls atmospheric circulation and the transport and convergence of atmospheric water vapor and hence precipitation.

(2) That a weak versus strong low cloud amount feedback has important implications not only for climate sensitivity but also the response of large-scale sea surface temperature gradients and atmospheric circulation.

(3) That there is a robust transient strengthening of the equatorial Pacific east-west temperature difference, and the associated atmospheric Walker circulation, in coupled climate model simulations wherein atmospheric carbon dioxide is abruptly increased (akin of an ocean thermostat). This transient strengthening lasts between 20 and 100 years, depending on how abruptly the system is perturbed. In contrast, the equilibrium response in these simulations where atmospheric carbon dioxide is abruptly increased, emerging after ~50?100 years, is generally characterized by warmer sea surface temperatures in the eastern equatorial Pacific, reduced zonal winds, and a weaker atmospheric Walker cell. The relative balance between a weaker versus stronger equilibrium Walker cell in response to CO2 forcing relates to the rate of tropical vs extra-tropical warming and slowdown of the oceanic subtropical cells.

Funding from this grant supported a female early career researcher, PI Burls, and a graduate student at George Mason University (GMU) working under the mentorship of PI Burls. Both PI Burls and the graduate student benefited from the collaborative nature of this grant, involving the interaction between scientists at GMU and Yale University.  At Yale the grant supported in part a postdoctoral associate and summer work by an undergraduate student who went on to defend a B.S. thesis under PI Fedorov?s supervision. The project also provided a framework for the research projects undertaken by several other graduate students and postdocs supervised by the PIs. In total, this collaborative project has resulted in nearly 20 publications, including in such journals as PNAS and Nature Climate Change. These publications cover a broad range of topics from the role of tropical and subtropical clouds in climate sensitivity to the response of the tropical Pacific to climatic forcing to ENSO dynamics. The results have been also presented at invited talks by the PIs at the AGU, Ocean Sciences and other conferences and workshops.

Another important goal of this collaborative project was to enhance the capacity for global climate modeling and analysis by graduate and undergraduate students at both George Mason and Yale. The project also generated unique internship opportunities for a total of 20 high school and undergraduate students through PI Burls?s involvement in GMU?s Aspiring Scientists Summer Internship Program during the summers of 2016 through 2020. These high school students joined Dr. Burls?s group to participate in ~7.5 weeks of research activities supported by this grant. These students also attended profession development classes as part of GMU?s ASSIP program. The ASSIP program receives several hundred applications from students across the US every year (over 900 this year) highlighting the clear demand for this type of research opportunity.
